creator: robert@repnak.de
text:
if you defined properties in an ant script, it would be helpfull, to have a 
possibility, to sent all these properties to an java program called with the 
<java> tag. at the moment you have to use <sysproperty> to send each 
property step by step.

robert

Hmmm... I assume that the java task is doing a Runtime.exec right 
now (didn't check).... but if we allowed it to launch via 
Class.forName, they would automatically inherit 
everything...  Although, I guess we could just pass every 
property as a -D on the command line, but that could be a problem on 
some platforms (AS/400, for example) that have a limited 
command-line length...

-- Malachi
creator: malachi@eoti.org

text:
There is now an <echoproperties> task to save all/some of the properties to a 
property file; you can then load these in to your app; all you need to pass 
along would be the name of the file to load.

Would that work, or is your need more generic?


...I am a bit dubious about passing all properties down, as the code would 
need to filter out those ones like java.home that shouldnt propagate.

i don't see the difference between putting the properties in a file and then 
load this file and send all properties directly. you need a filter for both 
ways. again, the problem of the file solution is you can't start the same 
script 2 times at the same time.

have a unified approach for both junit and java; perhap w/ the ability select
subsets of properties like "test.*"
creator: stevel@apache.org
nicolaken@apache.org
text:
Reading now these comments, it seems that the best thing would be to patch the
Environment type and make it creatable from Ant properties withthe ability select
subsets of properties like "test.*" .

This way any task can just have an <environment subset="test."/> tag inside.

Starting with nightly build 2003-05-15 you can use

<java ...>
  <syspropertyset>
    <propertyref builtin="all"/>
  </syspropertyset>
</java>
